I'm intending to write a very simple extension to JUnit but before I do I 
wanted to check:

1. Whether its been done already
2. Whether I only need it because I'm doing something wrong
3. How this extension may get in to the next release.

There seems to be three levels of JUnit test running:
1. Run every test in every test-case.
	Solution: Suite of all suites, AllTests.java, use Ant.
2. Run every test in a single test-case.
	Solution: Standard JUnit run with a named TestCase subclass.
3. Run a specific test in a single test-case.
	Solution: Currently I have to modify a suite() method.

I'd like to see the last case possible without recompilation.

Currently I have code in my suite() method that looks like:

   public static final Test suite()
   {
      // Swap comments to apply all-tests / one-specific-test
      TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ExportTest.class);
//        TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
//        suite.addTest(new ExportTest("testEntityAttributes"));

This can lead to test suites being left in a state where all those hard written 
tests are not being run (just the last one I was concentrating on).


As an alternative I'm considering implementing the following extension:

java junit.textui.TestRunner my.package.ExportTest testEntityAttributes


Some might say that all tests (in a TestCase) should be run every time but my 
problem is that sometimes, when concentrating on a particular test, this can be 
too time consuming.
Personally, I also use JUnit for acceptance testing so this feature would be 
even more useful there.

What do people think?

Richard.
